text.p: NARODNA OBRODA - The National Bank of Slovakia (NBS) said it expected wage and fiscal policies to create pressure to lower domestic demand in order to improve the GDP structure.

- Troubled engineering company Podpolianske Strojarne may have to layoff almost half of its 2,600 employees if it does not get financial help. The company hopes to get a 150 million crown interest-free loan.
- The Constitutional Court is expected to rule on July 16 on an appeal against the language law which made Slovak the only official language in the country.
- The Association of Securities Traders (AOCP) has filed a protest to the Stock Exchange Chamber against an alleged upward manipulation in the price of shares of engineering firm Povazske Strojarne.
- A government proposal tying wage growth to labour productivity has yet to be approved by parliament and is proposed to take effect in October.
- Slovakia's sole oil refiner Slovnaft said it did not expect to be affected by the new wage increase legislation.
PRAVDA - The Confederation of Trade Unions (KOZ) said it had not been informed on the government's intention to introduce regulation of wages.
- Jozef Migas, leader of the opposition Party of the Democratic Left (SDL), said the economy was nearing a critical situation.
- The strongest Slovak trade union OZ KOVO, which groups employees of the engineering sector, said that if the governemnt moved to increase energy prices it would risk social collapse.
- Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar has left for a meting of the European Union and its associate members in Amsterdam where he wants to reaffirm Slovakia's desire to join EU as soon as possible.
- Parliament is expected to vote on Thursday on a law banning privatisation of the official Slovak Television second terrestrial channel. The draft was presented by the opposition SDL.
SME - SCP Ruzomberok, Slovakia's major pulp and paper producer, said it planned to invest some six bilion crowns over the next five years.

- The ethnic Hungarian parties in Slovakia said they would protest to the Council of Europe and the EU against a Slovak decision to hand out final school certificates only in Slovak, even at bilingual Slovak-Hungarian schools.

HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - Exports in the first five months of 1997 rose faster than imports. Exports rose by 13 percent year-on-year in the January-May period compared with an annual increase of 12.6 in imports.
